priorVersion.title: CDISC SDTM Respiratory Test Name Terminology

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C111107

self.title: CDISC SDTM Respiratory Test Name Terminology

definition: A terminology codelist based on the test names for physiological findings related to the respiratory system, including the organs that are involved in breathing such as the nose, throat, larynx, trachea, bronchi and lungs.
name: Respiratory Test Name
preferredTerm: CDISC SDTM Respiratory Test Name Terminology

terms.definition: The instantaneous rate of air flow in the airway, expressed as the pressure difference between any given part of the airway and the alveoli; it is the reciprocal of airway resistance (Raw).
A measurement of respiratory tract resistance to airflow during inspiration and expiration.
The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide expressed as a proportion of the alveolar volume.
terms.preferredTerm: Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide/Alveolar Volume Ratio

terms.definition: The volume of the carbon monoxide that is transferred from inspired air into the pulmonary capillary blood.
terms.submissionValue: Diffusion Capacity of Lung for CO
synonyms: Diffusion Capacity of Lung for CO
Transfer Factor of Lung for CO

terms.definition: A measure of the resistance of a system to expand, i.e. the pressure change that is required to elicit a unit volume change in the lungs. Elastance is the reciprocal of compliance.
The maximum volume of air a subject can exhale from the lungs after a tidal exhalation.
The maximum volume of air an individual can exhale from the point of maximal inhalation.
The volume of gas that is forcibly exhaled at the peak of expiratory flow.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume at Peak Expiratory Flow
synonyms: Forced Expiratory Volume at Peak Expiratory Flow

terms.definition: The change in FEV1 following administration of a bronchodilator relative to the pre-treatment FEV1 value.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second Reversibility

terms.definition: The ratio of the forced expiratory volume during the first second of exhalation to the largest observed expired volume during a forced vital capacity maneuver.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second to Forced Vital Capacity Ratio Measurement

terms.definition: The ratio of the forced expiratory volume during the first second of exhalation to the largest observed expired volume during the first six seconds of a forced vital capacity maneuver.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second to Forced Vital Capacity in 6 Seconds

terms.definition: The mean forced expiratory flow rate at 25-75% of the forced vital capacity. (NCI)
The mean forced expiratory flow rate at 50% of the forced vital capacity. (NCI)
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Flow at 50 Percent Forced Vital Capacity

terms.definition: The forced expiratory flow rate during the first 0.05 second of a forced exhalation.
The forced expiratory flow rate during the first 0.1 second of a forced exhalation.
The forced expiratory flow rate during the first 0.2 second of a forced exhalation.
The ratio of the volume of gas that is forcibly exhaled during the first 0.05 seconds following maximal inhalation to that of the forced vital capacity.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.05 Second to FVC Ratio Measurement
synonyms: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.05 Seconds over FVC

terms.definition: The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first 0.05 second following maximal inhalation.
The ratio of the volume of gas that is forcibly exhaled during the first 0.1 seconds following maximal inhalation to that of the forced vital capacity.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.1 Second to FVC Ratio Measurement
synonyms: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.1 Seconds over FVC

terms.definition: The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first 0.1 second following maximal inhalation.
The ratio of the volume of gas that is forcibly exhaled during the first 0.2 seconds following maximal inhalation to that of the forced vital capacity.
terms.preferredTerm: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.2 Second to FVC Ratio Measurement
synonyms: Forced Expiratory Volume in 0.2 Seconds over FVC

terms.definition: The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first 0.2 second following maximal inhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first half second following maximal inhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first second following maximal inhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first three seconds following maximal inhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first six seconds following maximal inhalation.
The forced inspiratory flow rate at the point on the inspiratory flow-volume curve where 25 percent of the total volume of air has been inhaled.
The forced inspiratory flow rate at the point on the inspiratory flow-volume curve where 50 percent of the total volume of air has been inhaled.
The forced inspiratory flow rate at the point on the inspiratory flow-volume curve where 75 percent of the total volume of air has been inhaled.
The difference in lung volume between maximal expiration to residual volume followed immediately by full inspiration to total lung capacity during forceful inhalation.
The volume of air that a subject can breathe in during the first second of inhalation after maximum exhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled following maximal inhalation.
The volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled during the first six seconds following maximal inhalation.
The volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation. (NCI)
The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide adjusted for hemoglobin concentration.
terms.preferredTerm: Hemoglobin Corrected Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide

terms.definition: The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide expressed as a proportion of the alveolar volume, adjusted for hemoglobin concentration.
terms.preferredTerm: Hemoglobin Corrected Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide/Alveolar Volume Ratio

terms.definition: The change in IC following administration of a bronchodilator relative to the pre-treatment IC value.
The measure of the force of the column of air in the conducting airways.
The maximum volume of air a subject can inhale into the lungs after a tidal exhalation (IRV plus TV).
The maximum volume of air a subject can inhale into the lungs after a tidal inhalation.
The maximum volume of air an individual can inhale from the point of maximal exhalation.

A representative measurement of the number of times the volume of air in the lung at the start of the washout (the Functional Residual Capacity) must be recycled to eliminate the tracer to the pre-defined endpoint.
The greatest amount of pressure that can be generated by exhaling against a mouthpiece, which is a measure of the strength of respiratory muscles. (NCI)
The greatest amount of pressure that can be generated during inhalation against a fully occluded airway, which is used to measure the strength of respiratory muscles. (NCI)
The fastest rate of inspired air achieved during a forced inspiration maneuver.
The mean volume of the carbon monoxide that is transferred from inspired air into the pulmonary capillary blood.
terms.preferredTerm: Mean Carbon Monoxide Diffusing Capability Test
terms.submissionValue: Mean Diffusion Capacity of Lung for CO
synonyms: Mean Diffusion Capacity of Lung for CO

terms.definition: The rate at which oxygen is absorbed and utilized by any given tissue in the body.
The volume of oxygen per heartbeat consumed by the body while at rest.
The change in PEF following administration of a bronchodilator relative to the pre-treatment PEF value.
The maximum rate of air flow expelled through the mouth, endotracheal, or tracheostomy tube during a cough. (NCI)
The maximum rate of exhalation.
The time from the start of the test until the subject reaches his maximum expiratory gas flow rate.
The maximum rate of inhalation.
The maximal flow achieved during the maximally forced inspiration through the nose initiated at maximum exhalation. (NCI)
The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide

terms.definition: The proportion of the diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide to alveolar volume, expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide/Alveolar Volume Ratio

terms.definition: The maximum volume of air a subject can exhale from the lungs after a tidal exhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The mean forced expiratory flow rate at 25-75% of the forced vital capacity as a proportion of the predicted normal value. (NCI)
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Expiratory Flow at 25-75 Percent

terms.definition: Forced expiratory volume in one second as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second

terms.definition: The proportion of total forced vital capacity that is expelled during the first second of a forced exhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second Divided by Forced Vital Capacity

terms.definition: Forced expiratory volume in six seconds as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 6 Seconds

terms.definition: The fastest rate of inspired air achieved during a forced inspiration maneuver expressed as a percentage of the expected result value for healthy individuals with similar characteristics.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Inspiratory Flow Maximum

terms.definition: The volume of air that a subject can breathe in during the first second of inhalation after maximum exhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Forced Inspiratory Volume in 1 Second

terms.definition: The functional residual capacity as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
Forced vital capacity as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value, adjusted for hemoglobin concentration.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Hemoglobin Corrected Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide

terms.definition: The proportion of diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide to the alveolar volume expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value, adjusted for hemoglobin concentration.
terms.preferredTerm: Percent Predicted Hemoglobin Corrected Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide/Alveolar Volume Ratio

terms.definition: The maximum volume of air a subject can inhale into the lungs after a tidal inhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The maximum volume of air an individual can inhale from the point of maximal exhalation as a percentage of the predicted normal value.
The maximum volume of air a subject can inhale into the lungs after a tidal exhalation (IRV plus TV) as a proportion of the predicted normal value.

The greatest amount of pressure that can be generated by exhaling against a mouthpiece, which is a measure of the strength of respiratory muscles expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value. (NCI)

The greatest amount of pressure that can be generated during inhalation against a fully occluded airway, which is used to measure the strength of respiratory muscles expressed as a proportion of the predicted normal value. (NCI)
The maximal flow achieved during the maximally forced expiration initiated at maximum inhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximum exhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after slow maximum inhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The volume of air moved into and out of the lungs during breathing at rest as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
The total volume of air in the lungs after maximum inhalation as a proportion of the predicted normal value.
An evaluation of the perfusion of a specific lung segment. (NCI)
A measurement of the ability of the lung to store energy, which is required for passive expiration.
The static elastic recoil pressure of the lungs at a given lung volume.
The volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximum exhalation.
The ratio between the amount of carbon dioxide produced and oxygen consumed in one breath.
A representation of the exponential function described by the Salazar-Knowles equation, and an estimation of a subject's inspiratory capacity.
The difference between the volume at total lung capacity and the hypothesized volume at a transpulmonary pressure of zero.
The reflection of the curvature of the upper portion of the deflationary limb of the pressure-volume curve.
The maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after slow maximum inhalation.
A measurement of the airway conductance relative to lung volume. (NCI)
A measurement used to describe airway behavior irrespective of lung volume; it is calculated as airway resistance (Raw) multiplied by functional residual capacity (FRC).
The absolute volume of air contained in the thoracic cavity at any given point in time and at any level of alveolar pressure.
The volume of air moved into and out of the lungs during breathing at rest.
A measurement of the reflection of energy conservation within a given tissue.

The energy dissipated relative to the elastic energy stored in the tissue in a P-V cycle. (Fredberg JJ, Stamenovic D. On the imperfect elasticity of lung tissue. J Appl Physiol (1985). 1989 Dec;67(6):2408-19).
The total volume of air in the lungs after maximum inhalation.
A calculated value based on all factors that influence the flow of gas from the airway opening to the alveoli, including airway resistance, and tissue resistance of the lung and chest wall. (NCI)
